Author: Shaikh-Ubaid
Title: Unescape strings at tokenizer level
Body: related https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1783

Conversation.Prompt: what is the difference between u"abc" and U"abc" in Python?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Python, the "u" and "U" prefixes before a string literal are used to indicate Unicode string literals. However, in Python 3, the "u" prefix is not necessary as all string literals are Unicode by default.In Python 2, the "u" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal that is treated as a raw string. A raw string treats backslashes as literal characters rather than escape characters. Here's an example to illustrate the difference:[CODE_BLOCK_0]However, in Python 3, all string literals are Unicode by default, and the "U" prefix is no longer recognized. You can simply use a regular string literal to represent Unicode strings:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In summary, the "u" prefix was used in Python 2 to indicate a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix was used to indicate a raw Unicode string literal. In Python 3, the "u" prefix is no longer necessary, and all string literals are Unicode by default.

ListOfCode.Content:
# Python 2
u_string = u"abc"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"abc"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc
print(U_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = u"\n"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"\n"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)
print(U_string)  # Output: \n (literal backslash followed by 'n')

# Python 3
u_string = "abc"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = "\n"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)

Author: maorfr
Title: [jira-permissions-validator] introduce integration
Body:
part of https://issues.redhat.com/browse/APPSRE-7890

this integration validates that it can create tickets on all jira boards defined in app-interface. since the integration is using the same credentials as our jiralert instance, this actually validates that jiralert can create tickets.

it took quite a few attempt with ChatGPT to get a good answer: https://chat.openai.com/share/440407a1-df1c-4f1e-84b9-76ffec9fd918

Conversation.Prompt:
hey there!
quick question on working with the jira api, possibly even in python.
is there a way to check is i have permissions to create a ticket on a given board programatically?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can programmatically check if you have permissions to create a ticket on a given board using the Jira API in Python. Here's an example of how you can do it:First, you need to authenticate with the Jira API. You can use the jira library in Python for this. Install it by running pip install jira in your terminal.Once installed, import the library and create an instance of the JIRA object by passing the Jira server URL and your credentials:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace 'https://your-jira-url.com' with the URL of your Jira instance and 'username' and 'password' with your actual Jira credentials.To check if you have permissions to create a ticket on a specific board, you can use the can_create() method of the Board class. You will need the board ID to perform this check. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Replace '123' with the actual board ID you want to check.Running the above code will print whether you have permissions to create a ticket on the specified board or not.Note: Ensure that you have the necessary permissions to access the Jira API and retrieve board information. Additionally, make sure you have installed the required libraries (jira) for making API requests to Jira.That's it! This example demonstrates how to check if you have permissions to create a ticket on a specific board using the Jira API in Python.

ListOfCode.Content:
from jira import JIRA

jira = JIRA(server='https://your-jira-url.com', basic_auth=('username', 'password'))

board_id = '123'  # Replace with the actual board ID

board = jira.board(board_id)
can_create_ticket = board.can_create()
print(f"Can create ticket on board {board_id}? {can_create_ticket}")

The correct approach to check if you have permissions to create an issue on a board in Jira is to verify your permissions against the project associated with the board.To check if you have the necessary permissions to create an issue on a specific board programmatically, you can use the Jira REST API in Python. Here's an example using the requests library:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace 'https://your-jira-url.com' with the URL of your Jira instance and 'username' and 'password' with your actual Jira credentials. Also, set 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY' to the project key associated with the board you want to check.This code sends a GET request to the Jira API endpoint /rest/api/2/mypermissions to retrieve the permissions for the authenticated user. It then checks if the user has the CREATE_ISSUES permission for the specified project. Based on the response, it prints whether you have permissions to create an issue on the project associated with the board or not.I apologize for any confusion caused by my previous incorrect statement regarding the can_create() function.

import requests

# Jira API endpoint to check permissions
api_url = 'https://your-jira-url.com/rest/api/2/mypermissions'

# Replace 'username' and 'password' with your Jira credentials
auth = ('username', 'password')

# Specify the project key associated with the board
project_key = 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY'

# Send a GET request to the API endpoint
response = requests.get(api_url, auth=auth)

if response.status_code == 200:
    permissions = response.json().get('permissions', {})
    create_issue_permission = permissions.get('CREATE_ISSUES', {}).get('havePermission', False)

    if create_issue_permission:
        print(f"You have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
    else:
        print(f"You do not have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
else:
    print("Failed to retrieve permissions from the Jira API.")

Instead, it provides global permissions for the authenticated user.To check if you have permissions to create an issue on a specific board, you need to retrieve the project associated with that board and then verify your permissions against that project. Here's an updated example using the Jira REST API in Python:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace 'https://your-jira-url.com' with the URL of your Jira instance, and 'username' and 'password' with your actual Jira credentials. Set 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY' to the project key associated with the board you want to check.In this updated code, we retrieve the project information using the /rest/api/2/project/{project_key} endpoint. Then we check if the user has the CREATE_ISSUES permission for that project. Based on the response, it prints whether you have permissions to create an issue on the project associated with the board or not.I apologize for the confusion caused by my previous incorrect statements. Thank you for pointing out the mistake, and I appreciate your understanding.

import requests

if response.status_code == 200:

    permissions = project_info.get('permissions', {})
    create_issue_permission = permissions.get('CREATE_ISSUES', False)

    if create_issue_permission:

else:

Instead, you can use the /rest/api/2/mypermissions endpoint to check your permissions for creating an issue in a specific project. Here's an updated example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace 'https://your-jira-url.com' with the URL of your Jira instance, and 'username' and 'password' with your actual Jira credentials. Set 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY' to the project key associated with the board you want to check.In this updated code, we send a GET request to the /rest/api/2/mypermissions endpoint with the projectKey parameter set to the project key associated with the board. The response contains the permissions for the authenticated user in that specific project. ListOfCode.Content:
import requests

# Jira API endpoint to check permissions
api_url = 'https://your-jira-url.com/rest/api/2/mypermissions'

# Replace 'username' and 'password' with your Jira credentials
auth = ('username', 'password')

# Specify the project key associated with the board
project_key = 'YOUR_PROJECT_KEY'

# Send a GET request to the API endpoint
response = requests.get(api_url, auth=auth, params={'projectKey': project_key})

if response.status_code == 200:
    permissions = response.json().get('permissions', {})
    create_issue_permission = permissions.get('CREATE_ISSUE', False)

    if create_issue_permission:
        print(f"You have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
    else:
        print(f"You do not have permissions to create an issue on project {project_key}.")
else:
    print("Failed to retrieve permissions from the Jira API.")

Author: samuel500
Title: Changed: Paragraph and Sentence Tokenizer Documentation
Body: This improves the documentation for the Paragraph and Sentence Tokenizers to make it easier to understand and changes the structure of the tutorials.

Conversation.Prompt:
how can the documentation can be improved?

## File Splitting 

You can train your own File Splitting AI on the data from any Project of your choice. For that purpose, there are 
several tools in the SDK that enable processing Documents that consist of multiple files and propose splitting them 
into the Sub-Documents accordingly:

- A Context Aware File Splitting Model uses a simple hands-on logic based on scanning Category's Documents and finding
strings exclusive for first Pages of all Documents within the Category. Upon predicting whether a Page is a potential
splitting point (meaning whether it is first or not), we compare Page's contents to these exclusive first-page strings;
if there is occurrence of at least one such string, we mark a Page to be first (thus meaning it is a splitting point).
An instance of the Context Aware File Splitting Model can be used to initially build a File Splitting pipeline and can
later be replaced with more complex solutions.

  A Context Aware File Splitting Model instance can be used with an interface provided by Splitting AI – this class
accepts a whole Document instead of a single Page and proposes splitting points or splits the original Documents.


- A Multimodal File Splitting Model is a model that uses an approach that takes both visual and textual parts of the
Pages and processes them independently via the combined VGG19 architecture (simplified) and LegalBERT, passing the
resulting outputs together to a Multi-Layered Perceptron. Model's output is also a prediction of a Page being first or
non-first.

For developing a custom File Splitting approach, we propose an abstract class `AbstractFileSplittingModel`.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe current documentation can be improved by considering the following points:Add clear section headers: The information is dense and can be hard to follow without clear section headers. It might be beneficial to break the text down into sections such as "Overview", "Context Aware File Splitting Model", "Multimodal File Splitting Model", "Custom File Splitting Approach", etc.Use bullet points or numbered lists: Bullet points or numbered lists can be used to present the sequence of steps, features, or components of the models.Include examples or use cases: Providing examples or use cases makes it easier to understand how the tools are used in practice. This could be as simple as providing an example of a code snippet or a detailed walkthrough of using a specific tool in a particular scenario.Add visuals or diagrams: Diagrams and visuals are effective in conveying complex ideas, process flows, and structures. They can help users understand the architecture of models, how data flows through the system, and so on.Explain acronyms and complex terms: Acronyms like VGG19 and LegalBERT and terms like Multi-Layered Perceptron are technical and may not be understood by everyone. It is helpful to provide a brief explanation or link to additional resources for these terms.Provide information on prerequisites or dependencies: It would be helpful to know if there are any prerequisites or dependencies to use the tools in the SDK. Providing this information up front helps users avoid potential issues later on.Here's a sample revision of the first part of your documentation:OverviewThis guide will help you train your own File Splitting AI using data from your preferred project. We provide several tools in our SDK to process multi-file documents and suggest splitting points to create sub-documents. The main models we'll explore are:Context Aware File Splitting ModelMultimodal File Splitting ModelAdditionally, for those who want to develop a custom approach, we have an abstract class, AbstractFileSplittingModel.Context Aware File Splitting ModelThe Context Aware File Splitting Model is an initial, simple solution for identifying potential splitting points in documents. It operates by scanning the category's documents and locating strings that are unique to the first pages of all documents within the category. This model considers a page as the first page, hence a potential splitting point, if it contains at least one of these unique first-page strings.Here's an example of how to use this model with our provided Splitting AI interface:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Multimodal File Splitting ModelThe Multimodal File Splitting Model is a more advanced solution that considers both visual and textual elements of pages. It leverages a simplified VGG19 architecture for visual processing and LegalBERT for textual understanding. The outputs from these are passed to a Multi-Layered Perceptron (MLP), a type of neural network, to predict whether a page is the first page or not.Developing a Custom File Splitting ModelIf you wish to develop your own custom File Splitting model, you can extend our AbstractFileSplittingModel class.These changes provide clear delineation between sections, explanations of technical terms, a practical example, and a more concise description of the models.

ListOfCode.Content:
# Assume the necessary imports and initialization here
model = ContextAwareFileSplittingModel(...)
splitter = SplittingAI(model)
document = load_document(...)  # Load your document here
split_points = splitter.propose_split_points(document)

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe ConcurrentModificationException occurs when you try to modify a collection while you are iterating over it using an enhanced for loop (also known as a for-each loop). In your code, you are using the enhanced for loop to iterate over the values() of the blocksClicked map, and somewhere within the loop, you are modifying the blocksClicked map or another collection that it depends on. This can lead to concurrent modification and trigger the exception.To avoid the ConcurrentModificationException, you can either use an explicit iterator and the iterator's remove() method to remove elements from the collection while iterating, or you can create a copy of the collection before iterating over it. Here are two approaches to address this issue:Approach 1: Using an Explicit Iterator[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this approach, we use an explicit iterator to iterate over the collection and remove elements safely using the remove() method of the iterator.Approach 2: Creating a Copy of the Collection[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this approach, we create a copy of the collection (in this case, a list) and then iterate over the copy. You can modify the original collection outside of the loop as needed.Choose the approach that best fits your specific requirements and the context of your code.

Author: stnqls
Title: Features/university
Body:
# 배경설명
대학찾기 - /university api연동위해 model 정의하기


# 작업내역
대학,학과,실기,지역으로 구분해서 model정의하기


# 레퍼런스



# 주의사항 
1. **PR의 단위는 최대한 작게** 유지해주세요. (300~400라인, File Change 10개 이하 권장)
2. 리뷰어가 빠르게 리뷰할 수 있도록 **배경설명**을 상세하게해주세요 (링크, 스크린샷, 영상등을 포함하면 더 좋습니다.)
3. 특별히 **리뷰가 필요한 코드라인에 코멘트**를 남겨주세요
4. 작업이 완료되기 전 미리 PR을 올려놓고 작업시 발생한 이슈를 해당 PR에 쌓아놨다가 작업이 완료되면 리뷰어에게 리뷰를 요청하셔도 됩니다.

Conversation.Prompt: write code to get the middle of the screen for the current user display in python
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! To retrieve the screen dimensions and calculate the middle of the screen, you can use the screeninfo library. However, since I cannot directly install external libraries here, I'll describe the steps first.Install screeninfo:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Use the following Python code:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This code will get the resolution of the primary monitor and calculate the center. If you have multiple monitors and want the center of another monitor, you can adjust the index used in get_monitors()[0].Run the script to get the center coordinates of your screen.

ListOfCode.Content: pip install screeninfo

from screeninfo import get_monitors

def get_screen_center():
    monitor = get_monitors()[0]  # Assuming the first monitor is the primary
    center_x = monitor.width // 2
    center_y = monitor.height // 2
    return center_x, center_y

if __name__ == "__main__":
    center_x, center_y = get_screen_center()
    print(f"Screen Center: ({center_x}, {center_y})")

Conversation.Prompt:
You are a Python expert.
How can I create a deep copy of a variable?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! In Python, if you want to create a deep copy of a variable, especially for complex objects like lists or dictionaries that contain nested objects, you should use the copy module which provides the deepcopy function.Here's how you can use it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]The deep copy creates a new object that's a copy of the original, but recursively creates new objects for any mutable objects found inside the original. This ensures that changes to the original object or any of its nested objects won't affect the deep copied object.On the other hand, if you used a shallow copy (e.g., using copy.copy() or for lists, simply doing copied_list = original_list[:]), changes to nested objects inside the original would reflect in the copied object as well.

ListOfCode.Content:
import copy

original_list = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]
deep_copied_list = copy.deepcopy(original_list)

# Now, if you modify the nested list inside the original list...
original_list[0][0] = 99

print(original_list)        # Outputs: [[99, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]
print(deep_copied_list)     # Outputs: [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] (remains unchanged)

Author: starcat37
Title: typing - binlogstream.py
Body:
TODO
- [x] 테스트: 정상 작동 확인
- [x] 호환성: pytest
- [x] 누락된 typing 확인
- [x] 잘못된 typing 확인
- [x] docstring 수정

Conversation.Prompt:
self.__allowed_events_in_packet: FrozenSet[event.BinLogEvent] = frozenset(
            [TableMapEvent, RotateEvent]).union(self.__allowed_events)

타입 'frozenset[BinLogEvent]'이(가) 필요하나 대신 'frozenset[Type[TableMapEvent] | Type[RotateEvent] | str]'을(를) 얻었습니다 

이런 오류가 뜨는데 이유가 뭘까?  TableMapEvent, RotateEvent 모두 아래와 같은 형식이야.

class RotateEvent(BinLogEvent):
...

class TableMapEvent(BinLogEvent):
...

그리고 이건 BinLogEvent 클래스의 형태야.
class BinLogEvent(object):
...
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT해당 오류 메시지는 frozenset의 예상되는 타입과 실제로 전달된 타입이 다르다고 지적하고 있습니다. 예상되는 타입은 frozenset[BinLogEvent]이고, 실제로 전달된 타입은 frozenset[Type[TableMapEvent] | Type[RotateEvent] | str]입니다.문제의 원인TableMapEvent와 RotateEvent 클래스가 BinLogEvent 클래스를 상속받고 있지만, 클래스 자체를 직접 frozenset에 넣고 있기 때문에 타입은 Type[TableMapEvent]과 Type[RotateEvent]로 간주됩니다.self.__allowed_events가 str 타입도 포함할 수 있다고 나와 있습니다. 이 부분은 코드에서 명시적으로 나타나지 않았으므로, 어떤 부분에서 str 타입이 추가되는지 확인이 필요합니다.해결 방법만약 self.__allowed_events_in_packet가 BinLogEvent의 인스턴스만을 포함해야 한다면, 타입 힌트를 frozenset[Type[BinLogEvent]] 또는 frozenset[type]로 설정할 수 있습니다.만약 str 타입이 실제로 필요하지 않다면, self.__allowed_events에서 str 타입이 추가되는 부분을 찾아 수정해야 합니다.예를 들어, 타입 힌트를 다음과 같이 변경할 수 있습니다:[CODE_BLOCK_0]이렇게 하면 TableMapEvent와 RotateEvent는 Type[BinLogEvent]로 간주되어, 타입 힌트에 문제가 없을 것입니다.

ListOfCode.Content:
from typing import Type, FrozenSet
self.__allowed_events_in_packet: FrozenSet[Type[BinLogEvent]] = frozenset(
    [TableMapEvent, RotateEvent]).union(self.__allowed_events)

Conversation.Prompt: what is the best python parametrized unit test
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTParameterized unit testing allows you to run the same test logic with different input values. This helps to avoid duplicating test code and can be very useful for covering a variety of test cases without writing a new test method for each one.In Python, the unittest module provides a base framework for unit testing, but it doesn't have built-in support for parameterized testing. However, there are several ways to achieve parameterized testing in Python.Using unittest.subTest:The subTest context manager in the unittest framework allows you to execute portions of your test function with different parameters.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Using parameterized library:The parameterized library is popular and can be used with unittest and other testing frameworks like pytest.First, install it:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then, use it in your tests:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Using pytest:pytest is another popular testing framework in Python that supports parameterized testing out of the box.First, install it:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Then, write parameterized tests like:[CODE_BLOCK_4]Which method is the "best" can depend on your requirements:If you're already using unittest and don't want to add external dependencies, subTest might be a good option.If you're okay with adding an external dependency and are using unittest, the parameterized library provides a more concise way to define parameterized tests.If you're open to using a different testing framework, pytest is powerful and provides parameterization and many other features.Given its simplicity, flexibility, and feature set, many developers consider pytest to be the best for parameterized unit tests in Python.

ListOfCode.Content: pip install parameterized
pip install pytest

Author: max-sixty
Title: Use a bound `TypeVar` for `DataArray` and `Dataset` methods
Body:
- [ ] User visible changes (including notable bug fixes) are documented in `whats-new.rst`

Edit: I added a [comment](https://github.com/pydata/xarray/pull/8208#issuecomment-1725054516) outlining a problem with this

---

I _think_ we should be using a `TypeVar(..., bound=...)` for our typing, since otherwise subtypes aren't allowed. I don't see a compelling reason to have all of `T_DataWithCoords` and `T_DataArrayOrSet` and `T_Xarray`, though I might be missing something.

So this unifies all `T_DataWithCoords`, `T_DataArrayOrSet` and `T_Xarray` to `T_Xarray`, and changes that type to be bound on a union of `DataArray` & `Dataset` (similar to the existing `T_DataArrayOrSet`). This covers the bulk of our API — functions which transform either a `DataArray` or `Dataset` and return the input type.

This does require some manual casts; I think because when there's a concrete path for both `DataArray` & `Dataset`, mypy doesn't unify them back together. It's also possible I'm missing something.

One alternative — a minor change — would be to bound on `DataWithCoords`, like the existing `T_DataWithCoords`, rather than the union. A quick comparison showed each required some additional casts / ignores over the other.

Conversation.Prompt:
I don't understand why this `cast` is required:

```
    def backfill(
        self: Self, tolerance: float | Iterable[float] | None = None
    ) -> T_Xarray:
        """Backward fill new values at up-sampled frequency.

        Parameters
        ----------
        tolerance : float | Iterable[float] | None, default: None
            Maximum distance between original and new labels to limit
            the up-sampling method.
            Up-sampled data with indices that satisfy the equation
            ``abs(index[indexer] - target) <= tolerance`` are filled by
            new values. Data with indices that are outside the given
            tolerance are filled with ``NaN`` s.

        Returns
        -------
        backfilled : DataArray or Dataset
        """
        obj = self._drop_coords()
        (grouper,) = self.groupers
        return cast(
            T_Xarray,
            obj.reindex(
                {self._dim: grouper.full_index}, method="backfill", tolerance=tolerance
            ),
        )
```

Without it, we get this error:

```
xarray/core/resample.py: note: In member "backfill" of class "Resample":
xarray/core/resample.py:118: error: Incompatible return value type (got "Union[DataArray, Dataset]", expected "T_Xarray")  [return-value]
```

For context, `obj` is a `T_Xarray`, and `T_Xarray` is:

```
T_Xarray = TypeVar("T_Xarray", bound=Union["DataArray", "Dataset"])
```

Each of `DataArray` & `Dataset` have their own `.reindex` method, which each return `T_DataArray` & `T_Dataset` respectively.

Those are defined as:

```
T_Dataset = TypeVar("T_Dataset", bound="Dataset")
T_DataArray = TypeVar("T_DataArray", bound="DataArray")
```

So I can't see why it doesn't see the result as matching `T_Xarray`.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe issue you're encountering is related to the way that Python's type checking and generics work. The error message you're seeing is due to the type checker not being able to guarantee that the type returned by obj.reindex is the same as T_Xarray.Here's a breakdown of the situation:T_Xarray is a generic type that can be either DataArray or Dataset.Even though both DataArray and Dataset have a .reindex method that returns their respective types, the type checker cannot guarantee that the return type of obj.reindex is the exact same type as obj (i.e., T_Xarray).To illustrate this with a simplified example:Suppose we have two classes, A and B, and a generic type T that can be either A or B:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Both A and B have a method foo() that returns their respective types:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Now, if we have a function that takes an argument of type T and calls foo() on it:[CODE_BLOCK_2]The type checker has no guarantee that the returned type of obj.foo() is the same as T. This is because, from the type checker's perspective, T could be either A or B, and it cannot ensure that the type of obj.foo() matches the exact type of obj.This is why the cast is required in your code. By using cast(T_Xarray, ...), you're telling the type checker: "Trust me, the returned type here is the same as T_Xarray".In conclusion, even though it might seem obvious to us that the return type matches, the type checker cannot make that assumption based on the information provided. The cast is a way of providing an explicit guarantee to the type checker.

ListOfCode.Content: T = TypeVar("T", bound=Union[A, B])

def bar(obj: T) -> T:
    return obj.foo()

Conversation.Prompt: is 0x12345678 part of latin1?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTNo, 0x12345678 is not part of the Latin1 (ISO 8859-1) character encoding.Latin1 is a character encoding that covers the first 256 Unicode code points, which includes the ASCII characters and additional characters used in Western European languages. The range of values for Latin1 is 0x00 to 0xFF (or 0-255 in decimal).0x12345678 is a hexadecimal value that requires at least 32 bits (4 bytes) to represent. It is not a valid Unicode code point or ASCII character. It is possible that this value represents a sequence of characters or bytes in another encoding or context, but without further information, it is not possible to determine its meaning.

Conversation.Prompt: If I have a js userscript running in Tampermonkey, can I set, globally, that utf-8 should be used?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can set the encoding of a userscript globally in Tampermonkey by including a charset meta tag at the top of your script.Here's an example of how to include a charset meta tag in your userscript to specify that UTF-8 encoding should be used:[CODE_BLOCK_0]The @charset tag specifies the character encoding of your script, and Tampermonkey will use this encoding to parse and execute your script. By setting the encoding to UTF-8, you ensure that your script can handle Unicode characters properly.

Conversation.Prompt: Can that charset cause other errors or exceptions?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn general, setting the character encoding using a charset meta tag should not cause errors or exceptions in your userscript, as long as the encoding you specify is compatible with the content of your script. However, there are a few things to keep in mind:Make sure that the charset meta tag is placed before any other content in your userscript. This is because the meta tag needs to be processed before the rest of the script is executed.If you're using any external resources (such as CSS or JavaScript files) in your userscript, make sure that their character encoding is also set correctly. Inconsistencies between the character encoding of your script and the encoding of external resources can cause issues.If your userscript interacts with other websites or web applications, it's possible that those sites may use a different character encoding. In this case, you may need to handle character encoding conversions or transcoding in your userscript to ensure that data is handled correctly.Some older browsers or systems may not support all character encodings, so it's important to test your userscript on a variety of platforms to ensure compatibility.Overall, setting the character encoding using a charset meta tag is a best practice that can help ensure that your userscript handles Unicode characters correctly, but it's important to be aware of potential issues and test your script thoroughly to ensure compatibility.

Author: geohotstan
Title: Make __getitem__ TINYer
Body:
cleean refactooooooooooooors only (maybe)
still potential lines to be reduced in fancy indexing.
wip
wip
wip

Conversation.Prompt:
def __getitem__(self, val):
    def normalize_int(e, i, dim_sz):
      if -dim_sz <= e < dim_sz: return e if e != -1 else dim_sz-1
      raise IndexError(f"index {e} is out of bounds for dimension {i} with size {self.shape[i]}")
    orig_slices = list(val) if isinstance(val, tuple) else [val]
    if (num_slices := sum(isinstance(v, (slice, int, Tensor)) for v in orig_slices)) > len(self.shape):
      raise IndexError(f"too many indices for tensor of dimension {len(self.shape)}")
    ellipses_found = [i for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if v is Ellipsis]
    if len(ellipses_found) > 1: raise IndexError("an index can only have a single ellipsis ('...')")
    ellipsis_idx = ellipses_found[0] if ellipses_found else len(orig_slices)
    orig_slices[ellipsis_idx:ellipsis_idx+1] = [slice(None)] * (len(self.shape) - num_slices)

    tensor_found = [(i,v) for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if isinstance(v, Tensor)]
    orig_slices = [slice(None) if isinstance(v, Tensor) else v for v in orig_slices]
    valid_slices = [s for s in orig_slices if s is not None]
    valid_slices = [v if isinstance(v, slice) else slice(y := normalize_int(v, i, dim_sz), y+1) for i, (v, dim_sz) in enumerate(zip(valid_slices, self.shape))]
    start, stop, strides = zip(*y) if (y := [s.indices(dim_sz) for s, dim_sz in zip(valid_slices, self.shape)]) else ((), (), ())
    new_slice = tuple((s, e) if st > 0 else (e+1, s+1) for s, e, st in zip(start, stop, strides))
    # Shrink
    sliced_tensor = self.shrink(new_slice)
    new_shape = sliced_tensor.shape
    # Flip
    if (flip_axes := tuple(i for i, s in enumerate(strides) if s < 0)):
      sliced_tensor = sliced_tensor.flip(axis=flip_axes)
    if any(s > 1 or s < 0 for s in strides):
      # normalize if negative strides
      strides = tuple(abs(s) for s in strides)
      def num_zeros(step, dim_sz): return 0 if step == 1 or (y := dim_sz % step) == 0 else (step - y)
      # Pad: add pad at the end: [dim_sz] -> [dim_sz_padded]
      paddings = tuple((0, num_zeros(s, dim_sz)) for s, dim_sz in zip(strides, sliced_tensor.shape))
      padded_tensor = sliced_tensor.pad(paddings)
      # Reshape: [dim_sz_padded] -> [dim_sz_padded // s, s]
      new_shape = flatten([sh // s, s] for sh, s in zip(padded_tensor.shape, strides))
      reshaped_tensor = padded_tensor.reshape(new_shape)
      # Shrink: do [:, 0]
      new_shape = new_shape[::2]
      final_slice = tuple(flatten(((0, sh), (0, 1)) for sh in new_shape))
      sliced_tensor = reshaped_tensor.shrink(final_slice)
    final_shape, it_shape = [], iter(new_shape)
    sub = [0] * len(tensor_found)
    for i,s in enumerate(orig_slices):
      if isinstance(s, (int, slice)):
        dim_shape = next(it_shape)
        if isinstance(s, slice): final_shape.append(dim_shape)
        elif tensor_found:
          for i_ in range(len(tensor_found)):
            if tensor_found[i_][0] > i: sub[i_] -= 1
      else: # s is None
        final_shape.append(1)
    ret = sliced_tensor.reshape(tuple(final_shape))  # Reshape
    if tensor_found: # Fancy/tensor indexing
      for i,s in enumerate(sub): tensor_found[i] = (tensor_found[i][0]+s, tensor_found[i][1])
      dim = [i[0] for i in tensor_found]
      idx = [i[1].sign().contiguous().__neg__().contiguous().relu() * ret.shape[i[0]] + i[1] for i in tensor_found] # TODO first contiguous fixes torch+cpu_only CI, but it causes llvm to fail. Second one fixes llvm
      max_dim = max(i.ndim for i in idx)
      idx = [i.reshape(*[1]*(max_dim-i.ndim), *i.shape) for i in idx]
      sum_dim = [d+max_dim-n for n,d in enumerate(dim)]
      new_idx = idx[0].reshape(*[1]*dim[0], 1,*idx[0].shape, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-1))
      arange = Tensor.arange(ret.shape[dim[0]], dtype=dtypes.int32, requires_grad=False, device=self.device).reshape(*[1]*dim[0], ret.shape[dim[0]], *[1]*idx[0].ndim, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-1))
      ret = (ret.reshape(*ret.shape[:dim[0]+1], *[1]*idx[0].ndim, *ret.shape[dim[0]+1:]) * (arange == new_idx)).sum(dim[0])
      for idx_,d in zip(idx[1:],sum_dim[1:]):
        new_idx = idx_.reshape(*[1]*dim[0], *idx_.shape, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-idx_.ndim))
        arange = Tensor.arange(ret.shape[d], dtype=dtypes.int32, requires_grad=False, device=self.device).reshape(*[1]*(d), ret.shape[d], *[1]*(ret.ndim-d-1))
        ret = ((new_idx == arange) * ret).sum(d)
      if dim[0] != 0 and dim != list(range(dim[0], dim[-1]+1)) and len(dim) != 1: # special permute case
        order = list(range(ret.ndim))
        order = order[dim[0]:dim[0]+idx[0].ndim] + order[:dim[0]] + order[dim[0]+idx[0].ndim:]
        ret = ret.permute(order=order)
    return ret

def __getitem__(self, val):
    normalize_int = lambda e, i, dim_sz: e if -dim_sz <= e < dim_sz else dim_sz-1 if e == -1 else IndexError(f"index {e} is out of bounds for dimension {i} with size {self.shape[i]}")

    num_slices = sum(isinstance(v, (slice, int, Tensor)) for v in orig_slices)

    if orig_slices.count(Ellipsis) > 1: raise IndexError("an index can only have a single ellipsis ('...')")
    
    ellipsis_idx = orig_slices.index(Ellipsis) if Ellipsis in orig_slices else len(orig_slices)
    orig_slices[ellipsis_idx:ellipsis_idx+1] = [slice(None)] * (len(self.shape) - num_slices)
    
    tensor_found = [(i,v) for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if isinstance(v, Tensor)]
    orig_slices = [slice(None) if isinstance(v, Tensor) else v for v in orig_slices]
    valid_slices = [v if isinstance(v, slice) else slice(y := normalize_int(v, i, dim_sz), y+1) for i, (v, dim_sz) in enumerate(zip(orig_slices, self.shape))]
    
    start, stop, strides = zip(*[s.indices(dim_sz) for s, dim_sz in zip(valid_slices, self.shape)]) or ((), (), ())
    new_slice = tuple((s, e) if st > 0 else (e+1, s+1) for s, e, st in zip(start, stop, strides))
    
    sliced_tensor = self.shrink(new_slice).flip(axis=[i for i, s in enumerate(strides) if s < 0])
    
    if any(abs(s) != 1 for s in strides):
        paddings = [(0, -dim_sz % s if dim_sz % s != 0 else 0) for s, dim_sz in zip(strides, sliced_tensor.shape)]
        padded_tensor = sliced_tensor.pad(paddings)
        reshaped_tensor = padded_tensor.reshape(flatten([sh // s, s] for sh, s in zip(padded_tensor.shape, strides)))
        sliced_tensor = reshaped_tensor.shrink(tuple(flatten(((0, sh), (0, 1)) for sh in reshaped_tensor.shape[::2])))
    
    final_shape, it_shape = [], iter(sliced_tensor.shape)
    for i, s in enumerate(orig_slices):
        if isinstance(s, (int, slice)): 
            dim_shape = next(it_shape)
            if isinstance(s, int) and tensor_found: [tensor_found[i] for i in range(len(tensor_found)) if tensor_found[i][0] > i][0][0] -= 1
        elif s is None: final_shape.append(1)
    
    ret = sliced_tensor.reshape(final_shape)
    
    # Further fancy/tensor indexing handling here (omitted for brevity, as the logic remains largely the same).
    
    return ret

Design for it:
https://www.figma.com/file/0qInyxtj8DZ6thDesNat5M/Empty-screens-exploration?type=design&node-id=81-83069&mode=design&t=CfZIYa7YXq8H6fR7-4

Conversation.Prompt: im using angular, how can i detect if im on a wildcard route in a parent component of the router? Can i for example use ActivatedRoute if im in a parent layout component?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Angular, you can detect if you're on a wildcard route in a parent layout component by using the ActivatedRoute service. The ActivatedRoute service provides various observables and snapshot properties that help you get route information. However, it is generally associated with the component that is directly linked with the route.For a parent layout component that may not be directly linked to a specific route, you could use Angular's Router service to detect the active route. Here's a simplified example using Angular's Router service:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we listen to the router's events observable and filter it for instances of NavigationEnd, which signals that a route change has completed.We then traverse the ActivatedRoute tree to get to the most deeply nested active route, which is where wildcard routes would be defined. We check the routeConfig.path of this route's snapshot against '**', which is the path usually used for wildcard routes. If they match, we know we are on a wildcard route.This should give you a starting point to identify whether you're currently on a wildcard route from within a parent layout component.

Here, DecodeValue has been redefined to automatically infer the correct type of data based on the type key.The DecodeResult type is then created by mapping DecodeValue over each key of PrefixMap and creating a union of the results.Please note that you must ensure that you're using TypeScript 2.1 or later because Mapped Types were introduced in TypeScript 2.1.

Conversation.Prompt: how can I create muliple dataframes in python from one dataframe group by a date column?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo create multiple DataFrames in Python from one DataFrame by grouping it based on a date column, you can use the groupby() function from the pandas library. Here's an example of how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the groupby() function is used to group the DataFrame df by the 'date' column. The pd.Grouper() function is used to specify the frequency of grouping, in this case, 'D' for daily grouping. You can adjust the frequency based on your specific requirements, such as 'M' for monthly grouping or 'Y' for yearly grouping.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. You can perform any additional operations or analysis on each new DataFrame as needed.Note that the above example assumes you have a pandas DataFrame named 'df' with a column named 'date' containing datetime values. Adjust the code accordingly if your DataFrame or column names differ.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Assuming you have a DataFrame named 'df' with a 'date' column

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type if it's not already
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # 'group_name' is the date value
    # 'group_data' is the corresponding data for that date
    
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)

Author: acreturs
Title: [BACK-69] Improving Categories and making them more specific
Body:
### Description of Issue ( new by @thomas-woehrle )

Compared to the first version there should be less categories. They are too fine-granular at the moment. Try to cut it down to 4-6 categories.
Prompts of first version were not ideal.

Overall there were several improvements to be made to the categorization method to be fully functional

Vague example of what i mean: https://chat.openai.com/share/48bd44b4-13a7-4ff8-9938-2214f0b17f6b
### How I implemented ( new by @thomas-woehrle  )

- adjusted getRepositoryTopics to return a list of strings rather than a string
- input to getCategoryByNumber is a list of topics and a description, but can be null
- call to GPT to get a number/multiple numbers for a project
- I use numbers instead of strings because this does leave no room for GPT to make up stuff like new category names
- transforms GPTs answer into a list of Categories

### Other ( new by @thomas-woehrle )

Author: Dev-Yesung
Title: [4기 고예성] Mission 1 PR 제출합니다.
Body:
## 📌 과제 설명
- [x]  JPA 프로젝트를 세팅해본다.
- [x]  세팅한 프로젝트를 이용해서 단일 엔티티를 이용한 CRUD를 구현한다.
    - 고객(Customer) 엔티티는 ID(PK), 이름, 성을 가진다.
    - 고객엔티티를 이용한 CRUD를 구현한다.

Conversation.Prompt: GPT야 JPA를 사용할 때 DB에서 id값을 가져와야되 이럴때 entity의 생성자에서는 굳이 id에 관한 생성자를 만들어 줄 필요는 없는거야? 왜 그런거야?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT맞습니다, JPA를 사용할 때 Entity의 생성자에서 ID에 관한 생성자를 만들어 주지 않아도 됩니다. JPA에서는 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식과 객체 생성 방식 때문에 해당 생성자를 만들 필요가 없습니다.JPA에서 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식은 크게 두 가지로 나뉩니다:자동 생성 (Auto-generated ID): 일반적으로 RDBMS에서 많이 사용되는 방식으로, 데이터베이스가 Entity가 저장될 때 자동으로 ID 값을 생성해주는 방식입니다. 대표적으로 AUTO_INCREMENT와 같은 기능이 이에 해당합니다.수동 생성 (Manual ID assignment): 개발자가 직접 ID 값을 설정하는 방식입니다. 주로 외부 시스템과의 데이터 동기화 등 특수한 경우에 사용됩니다.대부분의 경우, ID 값은 데이터베이스에서 자동으로 생성되기 때문에 생성자에서 ID 값을 명시적으로 받을 필요가 없습니다. JPA는 Entity가 영속성 컨텍스트에 추가될 때 ID 값을 확인하고 적절한 방식으로 설정해주기 때문입니다.Entity 클래스는 보통 기본 생성자를 만들어주는 것이 권장됩니다. 이렇게 기본 생성자를 만들어두면 JPA가 객체를 생성하고 초기화할 때 사용하게 됩니다. 만약 개발자가 특정 생성자를 정의하고 있는데 기본 생성자가 없다면 JPA가 Entity를 올바르게 생성할 수 없을 수 있습니다.예를 들어, JPA가 기본 생성자를 찾지 못해 오류가 발생하는 상황:[CODE_BLOCK_0]이 경우, JPA는 기본 생성자를 찾을 수 없기 때문에 오류가 발생할 수 있습니다. 따라서 기본 생성자를 추가하는 것이 좋습니다:[CODE_BLOCK_1]결론적으로, JPA에서 ID 값을 가져오는 경우 Entity의 생성자에 ID에 관한 매개변수를 추가할 필요는 없습니다. JPA가 올바른 방식으로 ID 값을 설정하고 객체를 생성하도록 기본 생성자를 제공하는 것이 중요합니다.

Author: erobitschek
Title: Initial commit
Body: Initial commit with better modularization

Conversation.Prompt: Explain Python enums with an example.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Python, an enumeration (enum) is a symbolic name for a set of values. Enums are implemented as classes, and you can use them to create sets of constants for use with variables and properties.Here's a quick example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we import Enum and auto from the enum standard library module. We then define a Color enum with three members: RED, GREEN, and BLUE. Using auto(), Python automatically assigns values starting from 1.Enumerations are iterable, immutable, and hashable. You can compare them using identity (is) or equality (==), but not with ordering comparisons (<, >, etc.).

ListOfCode.Content:
from enum import Enum, auto

class Color(Enum):
    RED = auto()
    GREEN = auto()
    BLUE = auto()

# Accessing enum members
print(Color.RED)  # Output: Color.RED
print(Color.RED.name)  # Output: 'RED'
print(Color.RED.value)  # Output: 1 (auto() assigns values starting from 1)

# Iterating through enum
for color in Color:
    print(color)

Author: MichaelSnowden
Title: Make all Go source file names snake case
Body: **What changed?** I renamed all of our Go source code files so that they're snake case instead of camel case. **Why?** This was an annoying inconsistency we carried over from much older code in the repo. **How did you test it?** The renaming process was part of an automated script (https://gist.github.com/MichaelSnowden/47576fffe27aa1cae6b26eaccec7ab55), so it should be consistent. Also, I don't see us doing anything in our codebase that involves parsing our own source files by path: *PS: here's a link to the GPT convo I had to generate this renaming script: https://chat.openai.com/share/7f2d011a-a8da-4fa4-9c6d-e09102fdd49f* **Potential risks** Mainly merge conflicts, but I used `git mv` so that these are renames instead of deletes/adds, so that shouldn't be a big issue. **Is hotfix candidate?** No.

Conversation.Prompt: My codebase has a lot of old Go code which uses camel case file names like `tlsConfigHelper.go`. I'd like for all of these files to be renamed to use snake case like `tls_config_helper.go`. Can you write a bash script which will do this?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! Here's a bash script that can help you rename the Go files from camel case to snake case:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Make sure to replace /path/to/your/codebase with the actual path to your codebase's root folder.Here's how the script works:It changes the current directory to your codebase root folder.It uses the find command to search for all Go files with camel case names.The resulting file paths are filtered using grep to exclude files that don't have a lowercase followed by an uppercase letter in their paths.For each file, it extracts the directory and base name.It converts the camel case base name to snake case using sed and tr.It constructs the new file name by appending the snake case base name to the original directory path.It renames the file using the mv command.Finally, it prints a message indicating the file has been renamed.Please be cautious when running scripts that modify your codebase, and consider making a backup or using version control before executing this script.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
cd /path/to/your/codebase

# Find all Go files with camel case names
files=$(find . -type f -name "*.go" | grep -P '.*\/[a-z]+[A-Z]+.*')

# Loop through each file and rename it
for file in $files; do
  # Get the file's directory and base name
  dir=$(dirname "$file")
  base=$(basename "$file")

  # Convert camel case to snake case
  snake_case=$(echo "$base" | sed -E 's/([^A-Z])([A-Z])/\1_\2/g' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')

  # Construct the new file name
  new_name="$dir/$(dirname "$base")_$snake_case"

  # Rename the file
  mv "$file" "$new_name"

  echo "Renamed $file to $new_name"
done

import os
import re

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
os.chdir('/path/to/your/codebase')

# Regex pattern to match camel case file names
pattern = re.compile(r'.*/([a-z]+[A-Z]+.*)\.go$')

# Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
    for file in files:
        # Check if the file is a Go file with camel case name
        match = pattern.match(os.path.join(root, file))
        if match:
            old_name = match.group(1)
            new_name = re.sub(r'([a-z])([A-Z])', r'\1_\2', old_name).lower() + '.go'
            new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

            # Rename the file
            os.rename(os.path.join(root, file), new_path)
            print(f"Renamed {os.path.join(root, file)} to {new_path}")

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    result = ""
    for i, char in enumerate(name):
        if char.isupper() and (i == 0 or (i > 0 and name[i-1].islower())):
            result += char.lower()
        elif char.isupper() and i > 0:
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                old_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                new_name = camel_to_snake(file[:-3]) + '.go'
                new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

                # Rename the file using 'git mv'
                git_mv(old_path, new_path)
                print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

                # Update go:generate statements in the file
                update_generate_statements(new_path)
                print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    name = name.replace("nDC", "ndc")

    result = ""
    prev_char = ""
    for char in name:
        if char.isupper() and prev_char.islower():
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
        prev_char = char
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def rename_file(old_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv' and updates go:generate statements."""
    base_name = os.path.basename(old_path)
    new_name = None

    if base_name.endswith("Test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("Test.go")]
        new_name = "test_" + camel_to_snake(prefix) + ".go"
    else:
        new_name = camel_to_snake(base_name)

    new_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(old_path), new_name)
    git_mv(old_path, new_path)
    print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

    update_generate_statements(new_path)
    print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                rename_file(file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-source\s+(\S+)\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_source = match[0]
                new_source = camel_to_snake(old_source)
                old_destination = match[1]
                new_destination = camel_to_snake(old_destination)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_source, new_source).replace(old_destination, new_destination)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

Conversation.Prompt: There could also be aux_files, and some source files could be named $GOFILE. Instead, just look for any `//go:generate` lines, find all Go source code file names on that line, and make them snake case
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTApologies for the confusion. I understand your requirement now. We can update the update_generate_statements function to find all the Go source code file names in the //go:generate line and make them snake case. Here's the updated function:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated version, the update_generate_statements function uses a regex pattern to match the //go:generate lines in the file. It then finds all the Go source code file names on that line using another regex pattern. For each file name, it replaces the old name with the snake case version using the camel_to_snake function. Finally, it replaces the original go:generate line with the updated line in the file content.Please replace the update_generate_statements function in the previous script with this updated version.Let me know if you have any further questions or require additional assistance!

ListOfCode.Content:
def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements
        pattern = r'(?m)^//go:generate\s+(.*)$'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                generate_line = match
                updated_line = generate_line

                # Find Go source code file names on the line
                file_names = re.findall(r'\b(\w+\.go)\b', generate_line)
                if file_names:
                    for old_name in file_names:
                        new_name = camel_to_snake(old_name)
                        updated_line = updated_line.replace(old_name, new_name)

                # Replace the go:generate line with the updated one
                updated_content = content.replace(generate_line, updated_line)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

It creates a temporary directory to perform the test operations and cleans it up after the tests are completed.The test_camel_to_snake function verifies the correctness of the camel_to_snake function by checking its output for different inputs.The test_rename_file function tests the rename_file function by creating a dummy Go file, renaming it, and then checking if the file is renamed and if the go:generate statement is updated correctly.The test_update_generate_statements function tests the update_generate_statements function by creating a dummy Go file, updating the go:generate statement, and then checking if the statement is updated correctly.To run the test, save the script as, for example, test_script.py, and run it using the Python interpreter:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Make sure you have the necessary dependencies installed, such as the unittest module.Let me know if you have any further questions or require additional assistance!

import os
import shutil
import tempfile
import unittest
from script import camel_to_snake, rename_file, update_generate_statements

class ScriptTest(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self.test_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp()

    def tearDown(self):
        shutil.rmtree(self.test_dir)

    def test_camel_to_snake(self):
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("camelCase"), "camel_case")
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("dcRedirectionPolicy_mock.go"), "dc_redirection_policy_mock.go")
        self.assertEqual(camel_to_snake("nDCHistoryResender_mock.go"), "ndc_historyresender_mock.go")

    def test_rename_file(self):
        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Rename the file
        rename_file(file_path)

        # Check if the file is renamed
        self.assertFalse(os.path.exists(file_path))
        self.assertTrue(os.path.exists(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go")))

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go"), "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

    def test_update_generate_statements(self):
        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Update go:generate statements
        update_generate_statements(file_path)

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(file_path, "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()

Title: Feature/fix reload
Body:
## Merge Overview

## Scope of Influenced

* .mainProcess.js

* 2023/06/10

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTこのコードでは、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでファイルの変更を監視しており、変更があるとhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出しています。しかし、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、引数としてfilePathしか渡していません。修正するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、適切な引数で呼び出す必要があります。具体的には、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの定義を以下のように修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_0]handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの呼び出し元で、handleGetFileEncodingメソッドを使用してencodingを取得し、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドに渡す必要があります。具体的には、handleMainメソッドの以下の部分を修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_1]これにより、handleLoadメソッドが正しい引数で呼び出され、不要な追加のリロードとコンソールログが発生しなくなるはずです。

ChatGPThandleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でファイルの変更を監視する際に、イベントハンドラーが2回呼び出されることが原因です。これは、fs.watchメソッドが変更イベント(change)が発生した場合に複数回呼び出されることがあるためです。この問題を解決するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内で最初の変更イベントが発生した時点でイベントハンドラーを一時的に無効化し、2回目以降の呼び出しを無視する必要があります。以下は修正例です：[CODE_BLOCK_0]上記の修正では、最初の変更イベントが発生した後、1秒間の間は監視フラグが無効化されます。その間に発生する変更イベントは無視されます。1秒後に監視フラグが再度有効化されるため、その後の変更イベントが再び処理されるようになります。この修正により、1回のファイル変更に対して1回のコンソールログと1回のリロードが行われるはずです。必要に応じて、無視する時間間隔を調整してください。

Here's a general outline of the steps involved:Obtain API credentials: Register your application on both the StreamElements Developer Portal (https://streamelements.com/dashboard/account/developer) and the Twitch Developer Portal (https://dev.twitch.tv/). The specific API endpoint or method for this may vary based on the StreamElements API documentation. Conversation.Prompt: I don't want to get the info as I already have it. I just want to find out if a string is a twitch loginname or StreamElements Account ID based on it's format
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo determine if a string is a Twitch login name or a StreamElements account ID based on its format, you can use regular expressions. Regular expressions are a powerful tool for pattern matching and can help identify specific patterns within strings.Here's an example of how you can use regular expressions to differentiate between Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the regular expression patterns twitch_pattern and streamelements_pattern are used to define the expected formats for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, respectively. The re.match() function is used to check if the input string matches the patterns. If a match is found, it returns the corresponding identification ("Twitch login name" or "StreamElements Account ID"). If no match is found, it returns "Unknown".You can adjust the regular expressions to match the specific format requirements for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, if necessary.

ListOfCode.Content:
import re

def identify_string(string):
    # Regular expression patterns for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs
    twitch_pattern = r"^[A-Za-z0-9_]{4,25}$"
    streamelements_pattern = r"^[a-fA-F0-9]{24}$"

    if re.match(twitch_pattern, string):
        return "Twitch login name"
    elif re.match(streamelements_pattern, string):
        return "StreamElements Account ID"
    else:
        return "Unknown"

# Example usage
string1 = "mytwitchusername123"
string2 = "5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3"
string3 = "invalid_string"

print(identify_string(string1))  # Output: Twitch login name
print(identify_string(string2))  # Output: StreamElements Account ID
print(identify_string(string3))  # Output: Unknown

Title: Get backfilledResults to show non-empty.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYour existing implementation already has a lot of the functionality you're seeking. The Game class has methods to interact with localStorage, get and set user data, and display results.However, to render the contents of localStorage on every page load, you need to make sure you call the initialize() function at the start of each page load. It seems your code currently only creates a new instance of the Game class, but it does not call the initialize() function unless initializeImmediately is set to true.Update the last few lines in your game.js file as follows to call the initialize() function whenever a new Game instance is created:[CODE_BLOCK_0]By passing true as an argument when creating a new Game instance, you're enabling immediate initialization, which includes displaying the current user and the backfilled results.Regarding unit tests, here is an example of how you might write tests to check these functionalities using a testing framework like Jest:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Note: You would need to adjust the tests depending on the specifics of your implementation and the testing environment. This is just a starting point to give you an idea.

ChatGPTYour tests are failing likely because the initialize() function is called immediately upon the creation of the Game object. This function attaches event listeners to the respective buttons and selects. If initializeImmediately is set to true in your tests, the initialize() function will execute before you can set up your mock elements, which is why the tests fail.In your tests, game = new Game(); is being called in the beforeEach() block, which means initialize() is being called before any of the tests are set up. One way to fix this is to call initialize() separately in each test after you've set up your mock elements.Also, remember that if you want to check whether a method has been called, you need to spy on it. So instead of expect(game.initialize).toBeCalled();, you would use jest.spyOn(game, 'initialize') and then expect(spy).toBeCalled();.So here's how you could modify your tests:[CODE_BLOCK_0]

ChatGPTIt's understandable you'd want to prevent the automatic initialization of your Game class during the import, especially when running tests. It can be problematic because it could lead to unexpected side effects during testing, as it's running before the test environment is fully set up.A common way to handle this issue in JavaScript is to have a separate function or method to bootstrap the application. This function/method should be the one that creates new instances of your main classes and calls any necessary startup methods.For instance, you could create a new initGame function in your game.js file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, in your application's main entry point file (which might be a different JavaScript file that gets loaded in your HTML), you'd call this initGame function to start the game. This separation ensures that merely importing the Game class doesn't automatically create a new instance and run the initialize method.However, you need to make sure you're not auto-initializing Game elsewhere in your code. This approach requires your application to manually initialize Game in the actual application code (outside of tests).Finally, you'd import Game in your tests without it auto-initializing:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Now your beforeEach setup in your tests should run correctly without being interfered with by the initialize method. Your tests can create new Game instances and call initialize as needed.

Author: mikaylathompson
Title: Add MetricsLogger to the Capture Proxy
Body: ### Description Adds a MetricsLogger to the Capture Proxy. For now, it creates a limited number of events, with a limited number of dimensions. Events: - Component of request received (logged on `LoggingHttpRequestHandler::channelRead`) - Full request received (logged on `LoggingHttpRequestHandler::channelFinishedReadingAnHttpMessage`) - Sending message to Kafka (logged on `KafkaCaptureFactory::createOffloader` in the handler for a completed CodedOutputStream) - Message to Kafka failed (same as above) - Component of a response received (logged on `LoggingHttpResponseHandler::write`) All messages are logged with the `channelId` which corresponds to the `connectionId`/`diagnosticId` used throughout the Replayer. Some messages have additional context info, e.g. full request received also has the http method & endpoint. The event I would like to include but wasn't able to find already existing in our code is when a full response is received. I don't think this is an essential enough event that it's worth adding a HTTP accumulator to the pipeline, but if I missed a spot where this message is accumulated already, I'd like to add it. Events are logged in a json format (see example below). After playing with various text based log formats, this was by far the cleanest way to extract components as an AWS Metrics Filter, and should give us flexibility in the docker solution as well. To test this out, I created a metrics filter that looked specifically for "Full request received" events and plotted them while I did two `./runTestBenchmarks.sh` runs. Conversation.Prompt: I'm looking at some logging code that uses Slf4j's MDC to keep track of some extra context.  I'm in a highly concurrent environment though & MDC will carry its own risks.  Can I setup the same context directly through a log.atLevel()... fluent approach?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTSLF4J (Simple Logging Facade for Java) provides the MDC (Mapped Diagnostic Context) feature to associate metadata with current thread logs. This is especially helpful for tasks like tracking user sessions across application layers. However, in highly concurrent environments, especially when dealing with asynchronous programming (like using CompletableFuture, reactive streams, etc.), thread-local storage like MDC can be problematic.Let me explain the potential issues with MDC in asynchronous contexts:Thread-local Leakage: If thread-local variables are not cleaned up before a thread is reused (as in thread pools), there can be unintended leakage of the MDC values from one task to another.Lost Context: In asynchronous operations, the thread handling the initial part of a request might be different from the one handling the continuation. Thus, the MDC values can get lost if not explicitly propagated.If you're using the Logback logging framework (a popular choice with SLF4J), Logback does provide some utilities to assist with this, like the LogbackMDCAdapter which helps to manage MDC values.Now, as for your specific question about using a fluent approach with log.atLevel()..., you're probably referring to the newer, more fluent logging APIs (like the one introduced in Log4j 2).With the fluent approach, you can directly attach context data to a log message without storing it in a thread-local storage. Here's a basic example using Log4j 2:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To achieve this with SLF4J, you'd need to integrate or extend it with a logging framework that supports this fluent style.If you can switch or are already using Log4j 2, then it provides these capabilities out of the box. Otherwise, if you're committed to SLF4J, and if it doesn't natively support the feature you want (depending on the underlying logging framework), you might have to write some custom utility or wrapper to make it more fluent and context-aware without relying on MDC.A final note: If you decide to continue using MDC in asynchronous contexts, consider tools/libraries/frameworks like ContextAwareExecutorService or solutions like Project Reactor's Context (for reactive programming) to help propagate context correctly.

Logger logger = LogManager.getLogger();
logger.atInfo().withKeyValue("userId", "12345").log("User logged in");

const lastAssignCommentOfHunter = comments
    .filter((comment) => 
        comment.user.type === UserType.Bot && 
        comment.body.includes(assignees[0]) && 
        comment.body.includes(deadLinePrefix))
    .sort((a: Comment, b: Comment) => 
        new Date(b.created_at).getTime() - new Date(a.created_at).getTime());
if (lastAssignCommentOfHunter.length > 0) activities.push(new Date(lastAssignCommentOfHunter[0].created_at));

Conversation.Prompt: I have a react application and I have component that when property is true it will use provider from different library. Can I dynamicly import this library only when the condition is met?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can dynamically import a module in a React application based on a condition using the import() function. This is particularly useful for code splitting and lazy-loading components or libraries.Here's a basic example of how you might use dynamic imports in a React component:Setting up a new React app:If you don't have a React app already, you can create one using Create React App:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Using dynamic imports:Let's say you want to conditionally import and use a hypothetical library called SomeLibraryProvider. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Points to consider:import() returns a promise, so you can use .then() to handle the imported module.SomeLibraryProvider is dynamically set in the component state only after the library is imported.This approach will create a separate chunk for the some-library during the build process if you're using a bundler like Webpack (which is used by Create React App by default). This means the library will be loaded only when required, potentially improving the initial load performance of your application.Always remember to handle potential errors when using dynamic imports, like network failures. You can add a .catch() to the promise to handle these cases.That's it! You've successfully set up dynamic imports based on a condition in a React component.

ListOfCode.Content: npx create-react-app dynamic-import-example

Author: simonbukin
Title: Add map view
Body:
# Taxonium Map View

This PR adds a map view to Taxonium, which allows for tracking origins of samples in the tree.

## Screenshots

TBA

### [Video](https://streamable.com/7ozvpl)  (will need to be updated with a permanent link after expiry in a few days)

This is a pretty large PR, and I think some of the merge difficulty may come from the swap of naming from `taxonium_web_client` to `taxonium_component` (it took a little while to get this working locally).

The other more major change in the layout of the code was in `useView.js`, in which I switched to checking the `viewId` and using `setViewState` to compartmentalize the viewState updates. This was necessary because keeping both the map state (like zoom, latitude, longitude, etc) and tree state in the same viewState led to tons of problems and unexpected crashes when a viewState update for one view overwrote another. I'm a little weary that this change didn't introduce bugs in other parts of Taxonium, since I was mostly focused on the map view, so this is definitely something to check on.

Can definitely add more to this PR and fix any problems you may find. Thanks!

Conversation.Prompt: Write a DeckGL layer for pie charts
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTDeckGL doesn't natively support pie charts. However, you can create a custom layer to display pie charts on the map by extending one of the existing layers or writing a new one from scratch.Here is an example of how you might create a custom DeckGL layer for pie charts by extending the CompositeLayer. This example uses the SolidPolygonLayer to draw each slice of the pie. The data should include the longitude, latitude, and an array of values for each pie chart.Below is a basic example of how you can create such a layer:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Note: This code is not complete and is meant to be a starting point. You would need to fill in the details and handle edge cases according to your specific requirements. You also need to implement the getRadiusInPixel and toRadians utility functions, and the getArc function to generate polygons representing each slice of the pie based on the start and end angles and the radius of the pie.You would also need to provide the getColor prop to determine the color of each slice, and the radius prop to determine the size of the pie charts. The data prop should be an array of objects, each containing a position property with the longitude and latitude, and a values property with the array of values for the pie chart.

Conversation.Prompt:
tu es un expert react-native.
J'ai un compsant textinput il a un placeholder avec un texte qui peut être pus grand que la plac disponible sur ios il y a bien ... petit point qui se mettent automatiquement à la fin du texte mais pas sur android.
comment résoudre ce problème ?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTLe problème que vous décrivez concerne la gestion de l'affichage du texte dans un TextInput avec un placeholder potentiellement plus long que l'espace disponible sur iOS, où des points de suspension (...) sont automatiquement ajoutés à la fin du texte pour indiquer qu'il y a plus de texte à afficher, mais cela ne se produit pas automatiquement sur Android.Pour résoudre ce problème, vous pouvez implémenter votre propre logique pour gérer l'affichage du texte lorsque le placeholder est trop long sur Android. Voici une approche possible pour le faire :Mesurez la longueur du texte du placeholder.Obtenez la largeur disponible pour l'affichage du texte dans le TextInput.Si la longueur du texte du placeholder est supérieure à la largeur disponible, vous pouvez tronquer le texte du placeholder et ajouter des points de suspension (...) à la fin pour indiquer qu'il y a plus de texte à afficher.Voici un exemple de code en React Native pour implémenter cette logique :[CODE_BLOCK_0]Dans cet exemple, nous utilisons les hooks useState et useEffect pour mesurer la largeur du texte du placeholder et ajuster le texte du placeholder en conséquence. Vous devrez peut-être ajuster les valeurs de largeur disponibles et utiliser une bibliothèque de mesure de texte appropriée pour obtenir des résultats précis. Assurez-vous d'ajuster le code selon vos besoins spécifiques.

Author: displague
Title: Support deep frontmatter property setting using pydash
Body:
Adds support for deep frontmatter property setting using pydash. This allows, for example, the ability to define additional `tags` or set `author` details when there are multiple authors with multiple fields per author.

Dependencies were also updated to include `pydash` and bumping Python version to 3.11 (minimum stays at 3.7).

A Contributions section was added to the README.md with some of the tips that I picked up while trying to ensure the contribution met the project's expectations.

Fixes #5
